thread.title: FIT football team wins third straight
thread.title_full: FIT football team wins third straight

title: FIT football team wins third straight
text:
FIT football team wins third straight Michael Parsons , FLORIDA TODAY 10:32 p.m. EDT October 17, 2015 41 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
FORT VALLEY, Ga. — The recipe for success this season for the Florida Tech football team is quite simple — run the ball and play defense. 
For the third straight weekend it worked well as the Panthers improved to 4-3 overall with a 34-7 victory over Fort Valley State in a non-conference game Saturday night. 
“I think that we are still hit-and-miss on offense, but I guess we can’t expect to go out and score 40-50 points every week,” Florida Tech coach Steve Englehart said. “We had over 500 yards of offense and moved the ball well, enough to get the lead and let a lot of other guys play in the second half. Overall, it was a good team win.” 
Gary Holmes led the way with 103 yards on just 10 carries, scoring two touchdowns in the first half. Holmes did not play much in the second half but still managed his first 100-yard game of the season and second of his career. 
Mark Cato finished the night 8-for-19 for 187 yards, the biggest play coming late in the second quarter when he found tight end Kenny Johnston on a short pass play, and Johnston turned it into a 71-yard touchdown. That play gave the Panthers a 24-0 lead, which held up at halftime. 
For Johnston, it was his sixth touchdown of the season, tops on the team. 
But once again the story of the game was the Panthers’ defense, which held Fort Valley State to 168 yards of total offense. And in the first half it was all defense as they forced two fumbles and four three-and-out series. In the first quarter, the Wildcats had managed just four total yards of offense and had zero yards rushing at the half. 
Fort Valley State broke up the shutout with 4:18 left in the game when Drelon Freeman found Deion Perry for a 27-yard pass play. 
It was also a historic night for the Panthers as freshman Antwuan Haynes became the first player to return a punt return for a touchdown in school history when he took a kick 76 yards for a touchdown in the fourth quarter. 
“He’s been a dynamic player and I can’t wait to see what his career ends up to be,” Englehart said. “He is getting a lot of playing time as a freshman and having some productive games, and he is going to be good for us for many years.” 
Haynes finished with 138 all-purpose yards on the evening, leading the team. 
The Panthers got a scare on the final play of the game as Landon Galloway took a hit and remained down for an extended period of time. But he did get up and Englehart thinks he will be OK. 41 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://on.flatoday.com/1ROVG0b TOP VIDEOS
